strategy: Introduce a Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM) as an alternative to the Random Forest. GBMs can capture more complex patterns in data compared to RFs and might help in achieving higher scores.

actions.action:
cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split, GridSearchCV
from sklearn.ensemble import GradientBoostingRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model
gb_model = GradientBoostingRegressor()

# Set up parameter grid for GridSearchCV
param_grid = {
    'n_estimators': [100, 200, 300],
    'learning_rate': [0.01, 0.1, 0.2],
    'max_depth': [3, 5, 7],
    'subsample': [0.8, 1.0]
}

# Perform GridSearchCV
grid_search = GridSearchCV(estimator=gb_model, param_grid=param_grid, cv=5, scoring='neg_mean_squared_error')
grid_search.fit(X_train, y)

# Get the best model
best_gb_model = grid_search.best_estimator_

# Make predictions
predictions = best_gb_model.predict(X_test)

# Save predictions to submission.csv
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': predictions})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE

cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split, GridSearchCV
from sklearn.ensemble import GradientBoostingRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model
gb_model = GradientBoostingRegressor()

# Set up parameter grid for GridSearchCV
param_grid = {
    'n_estimators': [100, 200, 300],
    'learning_rate': [0.01, 0.1, 0.2],
    'max_depth': [3, 5, 7],
    'subsample': [0.8, 1.0]
}

# Perform GridSearchCV
grid_search = GridSearchCV(estimator=gb_model, param_grid=param_grid, cv=5, scoring='neg_mean_squared_error')
grid_search.fit(X_train, y)

# Get the best model
best_gb_model = grid_search.best_estimator_

# Make predictions
predictions = best_gb_model.predict(X_test)

# Save predictions to submission.csv
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': predictions})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE
